commitResults.messageTitle: Code now echos commands entered by the user
Code can now store whatever text entered by the user and display them back to the user when requested
Code now can mark tasks as done
Add support for tracking three types of tasks (Todo, Deadline and Event)
Code now able to handle errors
Add support for deleting tasks from the list
Teach the chatbot how to understand dates and times.
Update Parser.java, Todo.java, Task.java, Deadline.java, Event.java

Handle edge cases when description of a todo is empty, when description of a deadline doesnt have a /by clause, when description of an event doesnt include /from and /to clauses, when mark, unmark and delete dont have task numbers
Change file name duke.txt to Friday.txt
Remove unnecessary code to prevent potential conflicts during merging
Give users a way to find a task by searching for a keyword in the task description.
Update ListCommand.java, MarkCommand.java and AddTodoCommand.java such that the output is shown in the GUI
Update UnmarkCommand.java to produce output on GUI
Update FindCommand.java to produce output in GUI
Update ExitCommand to produce output on GUI
Update DeleteCommand.java to produce output on GUI
Update AddEventCommand.java to show output in GUI
Update AddDeadlineCommand.java to show output on GUI
Update code to correctly handle bye command
Handle edge cases of delete command
Use Scene Builder to tweak the GUI
Update code to be able to add multiple deadlines to the list all at once. Each deadline must be separated by "; "

Update code to be able to add multiple events to the list all at once. Update Parser.java to only check if the descriptions of deadline and event are empty, delegate rest of the checks to AddEventCommand.java and AddDeadlineCommand.java
Delegate complicated deadline and event checks to new classes checkDeadline.java and checkEvent.java
Add assertions for classes in the check package
Add assertions for classes in the commands package
Refactor command classes for modularity and separation of concerns
commitResults.messageBody:
The response generation logic in `AddTodoCommand`, `AddEventCommand`,
and `AddDeadlineCommand` was tightly coupled with the execution logic.
This made the command classes less maintainable and harder to test.

Having response generation in command execution violates the
single responsibility principle (SRP) and makes future modifications
more error-prone.

Let's refactor these command classes to delegate response generation
to dedicated response classes:
- Extracted response logic to:
  - `AddTodoResponse.java`
  - `AddEventResponse.java`
  - `AddDeadlineResponse.java`
- Updated the command classes to use the new response classes.
- Improved readability, testability, and maintainability.

Now, commands focus only on executing logic, while responses are
handled separately, leading to cleaner and more modular code.

commitResults.messageTitle: Commit Message: Remove unnecessary Ui class and refactor usages to support JavaFX GUI The Ui class was responsible for handling CLI-based interactions, including reading user input, displaying messages, and handling errors. However, since the application now uses JavaFX for the GUI, the Ui class is redundant.
commitResults.messageBody:
Why this change is necessary?
The UI logic has been fully transitioned to JavaFX.
The Ui class and its methods (showWelcome, showError, showMessage, etc.) are no longer needed.
The chatbot should no longer rely on Ui to handle interactions.
What has been done?
Deleted Ui.java since it is no longer required.
Removed all references to Ui in:
Friday.java
Parser.java
AddDeadlineCommand.java
FridayTest.java
UiTest.java
Updated error handling to use System.out.println() for now, where necessary.
Modified Friday.java to remove any calls to Ui and ensure commands still work with JavaFX.
Why is it done this way?
This keeps the chatbot cleaner and more modular, fully leveraging JavaFX for UI interactions.
Removing Ui improves maintainability by eliminating an unnecessary abstraction.
Additional Notes
Any remaining System.out.println() calls for errors will later be integrated into proper JavaFX error popups.

commitResults.messageTitle: Refactor FindCommand to use Streams API for better readability and efficiency Refactored the FindCommand class to replace explicit loops and manual string concatenation with Java Streams API.
commitResults.messageBody:
Current Issues (Before Refactoring)
Used a manual loop to iterate over tasks and filter matching tasks.
Created a StringBuilder and manually concatenated strings for output.
Used indexed loops for formatting instead of a more declarative approach.
Changes Made
Replaced the loop-based filtering with .stream().filter().collect(Collectors.toList()).
Replaced the manual StringBuilder logic with .stream().map().collect(Collectors.joining()) to format output.
Improved readability and reduced boilerplate code.
Why This Change?
Better Readability: The new implementation is more declarative and easier to understand.
Performance Optimization: Streams allow for efficient filtering and transformation of data.
Concise Code: Eliminates unnecessary loops and manual concatenation.

Why this change?
The FileManager class was redundant and no longer required for the chatbot's functionality.
Its responsibilities have been absorbed by Storage, making it unnecessary to keep a separate class.
Removing this class simplifies the codebase, reducing maintenance overhead.

Changes Made:
Deleted the FileManager class from the project.
Removed all references to FileManager from other parts of the code.
Ensured that Storage handles all file operations previously managed by FileManager.

Benefits of this refactor:
Code Simplification: Fewer classes mean easier maintenance.
Better Responsibility Allocation: Storage is now the single responsible class for file operations.
Reduced Redundancy: No unnecessary duplication of file handling logic.

commitResults.messageTitle: Update code to check deadline duplicates
Update code to handle duplicate event commands
Update code to handle todo duplicates
Used chatGPT to enhance quality of current code
Refactor package names to follow Java naming conventions
commitResults.messageBody:
Changed all package names to lowercase to align with Java's standard
naming convention. This improves consistency, readability, and
maintainability.

Following Java's package naming conventions ensures better
compatibility with industry standards and avoids potential issues
in case-sensitive file systems.

commitResults.messageTitle: Refactor class names to follow coding standards
commitResults.messageBody:
Updated class names to align with Clean Code principles and Java
naming conventions. Classes now use nouns instead of verbs, making
their purpose clearer and improving maintainability.

Examples of changes made:
- Renamed `CheckDeadline` to `DeadlineValidator`
- Renamed `CheckEvent` to `EventValidator`
- Renamed `CheckMark` to `MarkValidator`
- Renamed `CheckUnmark` to `UnmarkValidator`
- Renamed `CheckDeadlineDuplicates` to `DuplicateDeadlineChecker`
- Renamed `CheckEventDuplicates` to `DuplicateEventChecker`
- Renamed `CheckTodoDuplicates` to `DuplicateTodoChecker`

These changes enhance code readability and ensure consistency
across the project.

commitResults.messageTitle: Enhance error handling for invalid delete, mark, and unmark inputs
commitResults.messageBody:
Added improved error handling to validate user input for the delete, mark,
and unmark commands. The system now checks if the input is a valid number
and within the acceptable range of task indices.

Changes include:
- Handling non-numeric inputs by throwing appropriate exceptions.
- Checking if the task index is out of range and providing clear error messages.

This improves user experience by giving informative feedback and preventing
invalid operations.
